Data.event_text: 2 January  Buckingham Palace denies "any suggestion of impropriety with underage minors" by Prince Andrew, Duke of York, after he was named in U.S. court documents related to a lawsuit against convicted sex offender, American financier Jeffrey Epstein.

links.text: -"Prince Andrew sex case claim denied". BBC News. BBC. 2 January 2015. Retrieved 2 January 2015.-

Data.event_text: 3 January  Eight people are reported missing after a cargo vessel, the Cemfjord, capsizes in the Pentland Firth, Scotland.

links.text: -"Major search after ship overturns off north of Scotland". BBC News. BBC. 3 January 2015. Retrieved 4 January 2015.-
-"Cemfjord survivor chances said to be 'very slim'". BBC News. BBC. 4 January 2015. Retrieved 4 January 2015.-

Data.event_text: 4 January  The MV Höegh Osaka, a Singaporean cargo ship transporting luxury cars, runs aground near the Isle of Wight after it started listing shortly after leaving the Port of Southampton. An investigation is launched.

links.text: -"Crew rescued from listing Solent car transporter". BBC News. BBC. 4 January 2015. Retrieved 5 January 2015.-
-"Cargo ship Solent: Salvage team boards stranded vessel". BBC News. BBC. 5 January 2015. Retrieved 5 January 2015.-

Data.event_text: Figures from the last three months show that England's hospital Accident & Emergency waiting time performance has dropped to its worst levels for a decade.

links.text: -"A&E waiting in England worst for a decade". BBC News. BBC. 6 January 2015. Retrieved 7 January 2015.-

Data.event_text: Comedian and actor Stephen Fry confirms he is to marry his partner, Elliott Spencer. The couple are married two weeks later at a registry office in Norfolk.

links.text: -"Stephen Fry to marry partner Elliott Spencer". BBC News. BBC. 6 January 2015. Retrieved 6 January 2015.-
-Khomami, Nadia (17 January 2015). "Stephen Fry marries partner Elliot Spencer". The Guardian. Retrieved 13 February 2015.-

Data.event_text: 7 January  The SMMT announce that car sales surged in 2014 with 2.47 million new cars registered; a 9% increase from 2013 and the best annual performance since 2004.

links.text: -"UK new car sales surge to 10-year high in 2014". BBC News. BBC. 7 January 2015. Retrieved 7 January 2015.-

Data.event_text: Hurricane-force winds cause travel disruption and leave tens of thousands of homes without power across Scotland.

links.text: -"Hurricane-force gusts cause disruption to power and travel". BBC News. BBC. 9 January 2015. Retrieved 9 January 2015.-

Data.event_text: Circle Holdings, the first private company to operate an NHS hospital, announces plans to withdraw from its contract to run Hinchingbrooke Hospital because it believes the franchise is "no longer viable under current terms".

links.text: -"Hinchingbrooke Hospital: Circle to withdraw from contract". BBC News. BBC. 9 January 2015. Retrieved 9 January 2015.-

Data.event_text: Chancellor George Osborne says that tackling terrorism is a "national priority" and security services will get all of the resources they need in light of the recent Charlie Hebdo attacks in Paris, and the MI5 confirming that three UK plots had been recently stopped.

links.text: -"Osborne: Tackling UK terror threat a "national priority"". BBC News. BBC. 9 January 2015. Retrieved 9 January 2015.-

Data.event_text: Abu Hamza, the former head of London's Finsbury Park Mosque who preached Islamic terrorism, is sentenced to life in prison by a US court.Montage of Trafalgar Square and London Bridge being lit up in the colours of the French flag

links.text: -"Radical cleric Abu Hamza jailed for life by US court". BBC News. BBC. 9 January 2015. Retrieved 9 January 2015.-

Data.event_text: 11 January  Major London landmarks, including Trafalgar Square and Tower Bridge, are lit in the colours of the French national flag in tribute to the victims of the recent terrorist attacks in Paris.

links.text: -"Paris attacks: London landmarks lit in French colours". BBC News. BBC. 11 January 2015. Retrieved 11 January 2015.-

Data.event_text: 19-year-old Lewis Daynes who murdered 14-year-old Breck Bednar in  after meeting him online, is sentenced to life in prison.

links.text: -"Breck Bednar murder: Lewis Daynes sentenced to life in prison". BBC News. BBC. 12 January 2015. Retrieved 12 January 2015.-

Data.event_text: Security chiefs meet with David Cameron to review the risk of a terrorist attack, similar to the recent attacks in Paris, as the likelihood of such an event becomes greater.

links.text: -"Cameron discusses risk of Paris-style attack in UK". BBC News. BBC. 12 January 2015. Retrieved 12 January 2015.-

Data.event_text: David Cameron brands Fox News' terror expert a "complete idiot" after he claims that Birmingham is "totally Muslim" and "non-Muslims just simply don't go in".

links.text: -Holehouse, Matthew (12 January 2015). "David Cameron: US terror 'expert' Steve Emerson is a 'complete idiot'". Daily Telegraph. Retrieved 28 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: 13 January  Figures show that inflation rates fell to 0.5% in December, the joint lowest on record, mainly due to the drop in fuel prices.

links.text: -"UK inflation rate falls to 0.5% in December". BBC News. BBC. 13 January 2015. Retrieved 13 January 2015.-

Data.event_text: The Met Office warns that a storm, dubbed "Storm Rachel", will bring snow, ice, rain, floods and gale-force winds to the UK. This is after severe heavy snow and gales hit Scotland, and a tornado struck homes in Wales the previous night.

links.text: -Camilla, Turner (14 January 2015). "Everything you need to know about 'Storm Rachel'". The Daily Telegraph. Retrieved 14 January 2015.-
-"Snow and gales bring disruption to UK". BBC News. BBC. 14 January 2015. Retrieved 14 January 2015.-

Data.event_text: Ed Miliband, Nick Clegg and Nigel Farage, the leaders respectively of Labour, the Liberal Democrats and the UK Independence Party, write to Prime Minister and Conservative Party leader David Cameron to say that they will still take part in the planned pre-election televised debates even if he is not present. Cameron had said he would not take part unless the Green Party was included, but the other leaders call for the various broadcasters holding the debates to include an empty podium, enabling Cameron to be included if he changes his mind.

links.text: -Mason, Rowena (14 January 2015). "David Cameron under growing pressure over TV debates". The Guardian. Retrieved 14 January 2015.-

Data.event_text: A set of council offices, a funeral parlour, and a thatched cottage are extensively damaged after they are set ablaze due to a spate of arson attacks in South Oxfordshire. A suspect is arrested.

links.text: -"Arson attack guts Oxfordshire District Council building". BBC News. BBC. 15 January 2015. Retrieved 15 January 2015.-
-Matthew, Weaver (15 January 2015). "Suspected arsonist held over Oxfordshire fires". The Guardian. Retrieved 15 January 2015.-

Data.event_text: Ethel Lang, the last person living in the UK who was born during the reign of Queen Victoria, dies aged 114.

links.text: -"Britain's oldest person Ethel Lang dies aged 114". BBC. 16 January 2015. Retrieved 16 January 2015.-

Data.event_text: 16 January  UK counter-terrorism police warn that members of the Jewish community could be at risk following the recent terror incidents in Paris.

links.text: -"Paris attacks: UK police 'concerned' for Jewish community". BBC News. BBC. 16 January 2015. Retrieved 16 January 2015.-

Data.event_text: Sir John Chilcot says that his report into the Iraq war will be published after the general election. A draft version has been completed, but time is needed for those criticised by the findings of the inquiry to respond.

links.text: -Wintour, Patrick; Perraudin, Frances; Watt, Nicholas (21 January 2015). "Chilcot confirms delay to publication of Iraq war report". The Guardian. Retrieved 21 January 2015.-

Data.event_text: The Sun defiantly denies that it is to cease publishing topless women on Page 3 after posting a preview of its next publication featuring topless model Nicole Neal, calling the recent absence of the feature a "mammary lapse".

links.text: -Harp, Justin (21 January 2015). "The Sun defiantly denies banning Page 3 topless photos". Digital Spy. Hearst Magazines UK. Retrieved 22 January 2015.-

Data.event_text: 23 January  New proposals are published by the UK's major broadcasters to include the leaders of more political parties in the forthcoming televised debates. The BBC and ITV will now host seven-way debates between the leaders of the Conservatives, Labour, the Liberal Democrats, UK Independence Party, the Green Party, the Scottish National Party and Plaid Cymru. Meanwhile, Channel 4 and Sky will host head-to-head debates between David Cameron and Ed Miliband.

links.text: -"Election 2015: Seven-party TV debate plan announced". BBC News. BBC. 23 January 2015. Retrieved 23 January 2015.-

Data.event_text: David Cameron and Prince Charles fly to Saudi Arabia to pay respects to the late King Abdullah who died the previous day.

links.text: -Sparrow, Andrew; Perraudin, Frances (24 January 2015). "Prince Charles and PM fly to Saudi amid growing row over UK flag tributes". The Guardian. Retrieved 24 January 2015.-

Data.event_text: UK Independence Party MEP Amjad Bashir defects to the Conservative Party, describing his former party as one of "ruthless self-interest". In response, UKIP claims Bashir was suspended from the party over "extremely serious" financial issues, something Bashir dismisses as "absurd and made-up allegations".

links.text: -Jenkins, Lin (24 January 2015). "UKIP MEP Amjad Bashir defects to the Conservatives". The Guardian. Retrieved 24 January 2015.-

Data.event_text: 26 January  Libby Lane becomes the first woman ordained as a bishop in the Church of England (suffragan Bishop of Stockport), at York Minster.

links.text: -"Libby Lane: First female Church of England bishop consecrated". BBC News. BBC. 26 January 2015. Retrieved 26 January 2015.-

Data.event_text: 27 January  Helen Macdonald wins the 2014 Costa Book Awards with her autobiographical H is for Hawk.

links.text: -"Helen Macdonald wins Costa Book of the Year 2014". BBC News. BBC. 27 January 2015. Retrieved 27 January 2015.-

Data.event_text: 28 January  An earthquake of magnitude 3.8 is felt across the East Midlands.

links.text: -"East Midlands tremor recorded at 3.8 in magnitude". BBC News. BBC. 29 January 2015. Retrieved 29 January 2015.-

Data.event_text: 30 January  Commemorations are made for the fiftieth anniversary of Sir Winston Churchill's funeral, including a church service at Westminster Abbey, and the retracing of the same boat journey that carried Churchill's coffin along the River Thames in 1965.

links.text: -"Sir Winston Churchill's funeral marked 50 years on". BBC News. BBC. 30 January 2015. Retrieved 30 January 2015.-

Data.event_text: 31 January  The head of the Police Federation of England and Wales expresses his controversial support for all front-line police officers in England and Wales to be offered Tasers in light of the increased terrorism threat to the UK.

links.text: -"'Tasers for all front-line officers' – Police Federation". BBC News. BBC. 31 January 2015. Retrieved 31 January 2015.-

Data.event_text: 2 February  London's population hits a record high of 8,600,000 which it hasn't seen since the beginning of the Second World War in 1939, and is forecast to reach 11,000,000 people by 2050.

links.text: -"London's population hits 8.6m record high". BBC News. BBC. 2 February 2015. Retrieved 2 February 2015.-

Data.event_text: 3 February  MPs approve a controversial new technique to allow babies created from three people. If passed by the House of Lords, the UK will become the first country in the world to offer this medical procedure.

links.text: -"MPs say yes to three-person babies". BBC News. BBC. 3 February 2015. Retrieved 3 February 2015.-

Data.event_text: The entire cabinet of Rotherham Borough Council announces its intention to resign from office, following a report into the Rotherham child sexual exploitation scandal concludes the council's handling of the scandal was "not fit for purpose".

links.text: -Pidd, Helen (4 February 2015). "Rotherham council cabinet to resign after damning child exploitation report". The Guardian. Retrieved 4 February 2015.-

Data.event_text: Home Secretary Theresa May appoints New Zealand judge Lowell Goddard to lead a new statutory inquiry into historical child sexual abuse.

links.text: -Barrett, David (4 February 2015). "New Zealand judge Lowell Goddard to chair child abuse inquiry". The Daily Telegraph. Retrieved 4 February 2015.-

Data.event_text: 5 February  Former pop star Gary Glitter is found guilty of sexually abusing three young girls between 1975 and 1980.

links.text: -"Gary Glitter trial: Singer guilty of historical sex abuse". BBC News. BBC. 5 February 2015. Retrieved 5 February 2015.-

Data.event_text: Huge changes to England's NHS in recent years have been "disastrous" and distracted from patient care, a report by the King's Fund says.

links.text: -"NHS reorganisation was disastrous, says King's Fund". BBC News. BBC. 6 February 2015. Retrieved 6 February 2015.-

Data.event_text: The Investigatory Powers Tribunal rules that GCHQ breached human rights laws by failing to disclose shared full details of information it shared with the United States that was garnered from data from mass internet surveillance.

links.text: -Bowcott, Owen (6 February 2015). "UK-US surveillance regime was unlawful 'for seven years'". The Guardian. Retrieved 6 February 2015.-

Data.event_text: 9 February  A child and three adults are killed whilst four others are left seriously injured after a tipper truck crashes down a hill in Bath. An investigation is launched.

links.text: -"Bath tipper truck crash kills child and three adults". BBC News. BBC. 9 February 2015. Retrieved 10 February 2015.-
-"Bath fatal tipper truck crash investigated". BBC News. BBC. 10 February 2015. Retrieved 10 February 2015.-

Data.event_text: 11 February  The government announces a review into road regulations and maintenance checks in preparation for driverless car technology.

links.text: -"Driverless car review launched by UK government". BBC News. BBC. 11 February 2015. Retrieved 11 February 2015.-

Data.event_text: Former TV weather presenter Fred Talbot is convicted of indecently assaulting two boys while he worked at a school in Greater Manchester, and remanded in custody to await sentence. He is cleared of a further eight charges.

links.text: -"Fred Talbot: Weatherman guilty of abusing teenage boys". BBC News. BBC. 13 February 2015. Retrieved 13 February 2015.-

Data.event_text: The Prime Minister, Deputy Prime Minister and Leader of the Opposition sign a cross-party, non-partisan agreement to tackle climate change, seek a strong global climate deal, and to end the use of coal for power generation in the UK.

links.text: -"Party leaders make joint climate commitment". BBC. 14 February 2015. Retrieved 14 February 2015.-
-"Cameron, Clegg and Miliband sign joint climate change agreement". Green Alliance. 14 February 2015. Archived from the original on 14 February 2015. Retrieved 14 February 2015.-
-"Cameron, Clegg and Miliband sign joint climate change agreement". Green Alliance. 14 February 2015. Archived from the original on 14 February 2015. Retrieved 14 February 2015.-

Data.event_text: 14 February  Four people are killed following two separate accidents on major motorways; three die after a coach collides with a stationary car on the M1 and one person dies in a forty vehicle pileup on the M40.

links.text: -"Four Die In Coach Crash And Motorway Pile-Up". Sky News. British Sky Broadcasting. 14 February 2015. Retrieved 14 February 2015.-

Data.event_text: 16 February  A study by King's College London indicates an increased risk of psychosis among those who smoke potent cannabis.

links.text: -"'Skunk-like cannabis' increases risk of psychosis, study suggests". BBC News. BBC. 16 February 2015. Retrieved 16 February 2015.-

Data.event_text: Consumer price inflation fell to 0.3% in January, according to latest official figures, its lowest level since records began.

links.text: -"UK inflation rate falls to record low of 0.3% in January". BBC News. BBC. 17 February 2015. Retrieved 18 February 2015.-

Data.event_text: Abid Naseer, a man who plotted a terrorist attack on a shopping centre in Manchester in 2009, which would have reportedly only come second to the September 11 attacks in its impact, stands trial in the United States.

links.text: -"Man 'who plotted Manchester terror attack' goes on trial in US". ITV News. ITV. 17 February 2015. Retrieved 17 February 2015.-

Data.event_text: Five Britons are announced to be amongst the 100 Mars One applicants shortlisted for a one-way trip to Mars to become the first humans to set foot on the planet.

links.text: -"Mars One mission: five Britons shortlisted for one-way trip to Red Planet". The Daily Telegraph. 17 February 2015. Retrieved 17 February 2015.-

Data.event_text: 18 February  The Metropolitan Police says it will examine video footage appearing to show fans of Chelsea football club preventing a black man from boarding a train on the Paris Metro.

links.text: -"Chelsea fans Paris footage examined by UK police". BBC News. BBC. 18 February 2015. Retrieved 18 February 2015.-

Data.event_text: 20 February  Police appeal for help after it is feared that three London schoolgirls who have gone missing, are travelling to Turkey with the intention of crossing the border into Syria and joining a terror group ISIL.

links.text: -"Three missing London schoolgirls 'travelling to Syria to join Isil'". The Daily Telegraph. 20 February 2015. Retrieved 21 February 2015.-

Data.event_text: 21 February  The government pledges £300,000,000 for tackling dementia, aiming to become a "world leader" in research with a global fund to produce new treatments by 2025.

links.text: -"Alzheimer's charity hails one million 'dementia friends'". BBC News. BBC. 21 February 2015. Retrieved 22 February 2015.-
-"David Cameron announces £300m for dementia research". The Telegraph. BBC. 21 February 2015. Archived from the original on 21 February 2015. Retrieved 22 February 2015.-
-"David Cameron announces £300m for dementia research". The Telegraph. BBC. 21 February 2015. Archived from the original on 21 February 2015. Retrieved 22 February 2015.-

Data.event_text: 24 February  Conservative MP Sir Malcolm Rifkind resigns as Chair of the Parliamentary Intelligence and Security Committee, and announces he will vacate his seat at the general election, following a cash for access scandal.

links.text: -Sabin, Lamiat (24 February 2015). "'Cash for access scandal': Sir Malcolm Rifkind to step down as MP for Kensington". The Independent. Independent Print Limited. Archived from the original on 1 May 2022. Retrieved 25 February 2015.-

-Sabin, Lamiat (24 February 2015). "'Cash for access scandal': Sir Malcolm Rifkind to step down as MP for Kensington". The Independent. Independent Print Limited. Archived from the original on 1 May 2022. Retrieved 25 February 2015.-

Data.event_text: An independent report finds that Jimmy Savile sexually abused 63 people connected to Stoke Mandeville Hospital between 1968 and 1992, but the one formal complaint made was ignored.

links.text: -"Saville 'abused 63 people at Stoke Mandeville Hospital'". BBC News. BBC. 26 February 2015. Retrieved 27 February 2015.-

Data.event_text: The masked Islamic State militant known as "Jihadi John", responsible for the beheadings of numerous Western hostages, is named as Mohammed Emwazi from West London.

links.text: -"'Jihadi John' named as Mohammed Emwazi from London". BBC News. BBC. 26 February 2015. Retrieved 27 February 2015.-

Data.event_text: 27 February  Following his guilty verdict on 5 February, former pop star Gary Glitter is sentenced to sixteen year's imprisonment.

links.text: -"Gary Glitter jailed for 16 years". BBC News. BBC. 27 February 2015. Retrieved 27 February 2015.-

Data.event_text: 3 March  Disgraced entertainer Rolf Harris is stripped of his British honours.
4 March  The stepbrother of 16-year-old Becky Watts, a schoolgirl reported missing two weeks previously, is charged with her murder after body parts are found at a house in Barton Hill, Bristol.

links.text: -"Stepbrother charged with Becky Watts murder in Bristol". BBC News. BBC. 4 March 2015. Retrieved 4 March 2015.-

Data.event_text: 5 March  David Cameron is accused of "cowering" from the public as he confirms that he will only take part in one televised debate ahead of the general election, rejecting proposals for a head-to-head with Labour leader Ed Miliband.

links.text: -"Cameron denies 'running scared' of TV election debates". BBC News. BBC. 5 March 2015. Retrieved 5 March 2015.-

Data.event_text: A 13-year-old boy pleads guilty to the murder of 53-year-old Christopher Barry who was fatally stabbed in Edmonton, London, in December.

links.text: -"Boy, 13, admits Christopher Barry party row murder". BBC News. BBC. 6 March 2015. Retrieved 6 March 2015.-

Data.event_text: The UK's major broadcasters confirm they will press ahead with plans for three televised debates, even though David Cameron said he would only participate in one of them.

links.text: -"TV election debates will 'go ahead' say broadcasters". BBC News. BBC. 6 March 2015. Retrieved 6 March 2015.-

Data.event_text: Deputy Prime Minister and Liberal Democrat leader Nick Clegg says he will take David Cameron's place in the forthcoming television debates, if Cameron is unwilling to participate.

links.text: -"Nick Clegg: Conservatives 'arrogant' over TV debates". BBC News. BBC. 7 March 2015. Retrieved 7 March 2015.-

Data.event_text: A pitch invasion by Aston Villa fans temporarily halts the club's FA Cup quarter-final match against West Bromwich Albion. Several fans run onto the pitch during stoppage time to prematurely celebrate Villa's 20 victory over West Brom, forcing referee Anthony Taylor to stop the game until order is restored, before hundreds of fans then invade the pitch on the final whistle. The incident will be investigated by the Football Association.

links.text: -Burt, Jason (7 March 2015). "Aston Villa pitch invasion to spark Football Association investigation". The Daily Telegraph. Retrieved 8 March 2015.-
-McNulty, Phil (7 March 2015). "Aston Villa 2-0 West Bromwich Albion". BBC Sport. BBC. Retrieved 8 March 2015.-

Data.event_text: 8 March  Ed Miliband says that a future Labour government would introduce legislation to make televised debates a permanent feature of future general election campaigns, meaning politicians could not attempt to prevent them from taking place out of self-interest.

links.text: -Helm, Toby (8 March 2015). "Ed Miliband: I will pass new law to guarantee TV election debates". The Observer. Guardian Media Group. Retrieved 8 March 2015.-

Data.event_text: The UK Government finally pays off War Loan bonds, originally introduced to consolidate debt incurred in fighting World War I.

links.text: -Cosgrave, Jenny (9 March 2015). "UK finally finishes paying for World War I". CNBC. Retrieved 28 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: Thendara Satisfaction, an Irish setter who competed at this year's Crufts, dies after being supposedly poisoned at the Birmingham show. Organisers of the event say sabotage will not be tolerated, after rumours that various other dogs were also poisoned this year.Britannia cruise ship (pictured in 2021)

links.text: -"'No doubt' Crufts dog Jagger was poisoned, says owner". BBC News. BBC. 9 March 2015. Retrieved 9 March 2015.-
-"'No tolerance' vow after Crufts dog Jagger dies". BBC News. BBC. 9 March 2015. Retrieved 9 March 2015.-

Data.event_text: TV presenter Jeremy Clarkson is suspended from Top Gear, one of the BBC's most popular and profitable shows, following a "fracas" with a producer. The remainder of the series will be scrapped, the BBC says.

links.text: -"Jeremy Clarkson, Top Gear host, suspended by BBC after 'fracas'". BBC News. BBC. 10 March 2015. Retrieved 11 March 2015.-
-"Jeremy Clarkson 'punch': Top Gear episodes to be dropped". BBC News. BBC. 11 March 2015. Retrieved 11 March 2015.-

Data.event_text: Queen Elizabeth II names the new luxury cruise ship Britannia, the largest ever cruise ship designed for the British holiday market.

links.text: -"Cruise ship Britannia: Queen names P&O luxury vessel". BBC News. BBC. 10 March 2015. Retrieved 10 March 2015.-

Data.event_text: 11 March  The government announces the first NHS patients to be diagnosed through genome sequencing.

links.text: -"First patients diagnosed through genome sequencing". Department of Health. 11 March 2015. Retrieved 14 March 2015.-

Data.event_text: 13 March  Following his guilty verdict on 13 February, former TV weather presenter Fred Talbot is sentenced to five years in prison.

links.text: -"Fred Talbot: Ex-weatherman jailed for schoolboy abuse". BBC News. BBC. 13 March 2015. Retrieved 13 March 2015.-

Data.event_text: 15 March  Northampton Greyfriars bus station is demolished.

links.text: -"Northampton Greyfriars bus station demolished". BBC News. BBC. 15 March 2015. Retrieved 26 January 2024.-

Data.event_text: Chief Superintendent David Duckenfield admits that his failure to shut a tunnel to football terraces was the direct cause of ninety-six deaths at the Hillsborough disaster in 1989.

links.text: -"Hillsborough inquests: David Duckenfield admits causing 96 deaths". BBC News. BBC. 17 March 2015. Retrieved 17 March 2015.-

Data.event_text: David Cameron confirms he has accepted an offer from the major broadcasters to participate in a seven-way televised debate at the beginning of April. However, the full details of this are yet to be confirmed.

links.text: -"David Cameron 'accepts single multi-party TV debate offer'". BBC News. BBC. 17 March 2015. Retrieved 17 March 2015.-

Data.event_text: 19 March  One Briton is confirmed to be amongst the twenty-one victims killed in the ISIL backed Bardo National Museum shootings in the Tunisian capital, Tunis.

links.text: -"Tunis museum attack: Briton killed in shootings named as Sally Adey". BBC News. BBC. 19 March 2015. Retrieved 19 March 2015.-

Data.event_text: A partial solar eclipse occurs, ranging from 85% totality in London and southern England to 98% totality in northern Scotland.

links.text: -"'Breathtaking' solar eclipse witnessed by millions". BBC. 20 March 2015. Retrieved 20 March 2015.-

Data.event_text: UKIP MEP and general election candidate Janice Atkinson is suspended from the UK Independence Party after a member of her staff tried to overcharge EU expenses for a restaurant bill. The incident emerges as another UKIP election candidate, Stephen Howe, is suspended amid harassment allegations, and a third, Jonathan Stanley, resigns from the party because of what he alleges to be its "open racism and sanctimonious bullying."

links.text: -"UKIP in turmoil over general election candidates". BBC News. BBC. 20 March 2015. Retrieved 20 March 2015.-

Data.event_text: 21 March  The UK's major broadcasters say they have agreed to hold a seven-party televised leaders debate on 2 April, which will be staged by ITV and chaired by Julie Etchingham. However, there will be no head-to-head between David Cameron and Ed Miliband, with them instead taking part in a separate question and answer session aired jointly by Sky News and Channel 4 on 26 March. A debate featuring five opposition leaders will air on BBC One on 16 April.

links.text: -"Election debates agreement reached". BBC News. BBC. 21 March 2015. Retrieved 21 March 2015.-

Data.event_text: 22 March  Membership of the Scottish National Party officially crosses the 100,000 mark, meaning that one in every fifty of the Scottish population is now a member.

links.text: -"SNP boost as membership soars past 100k mark". Glasgow Herald. Newsquest. 22 March 2015. Retrieved 22 March 2015.-

Data.event_text: Afzal Amin, the Conservative candidate for Dudley North, resigns from the party after being accused of allegedly conspiring with the English Defence League to win votes.

links.text: -"Afzal Amin resigns as Conservative candidate in Dudley North". BBC News. BBC. 23 March 2015. Retrieved 23 March 2015.-

Data.event_text: David Cameron tells BBC News he will not serve a third term as prime minister if the Conservatives are re-elected in the upcoming general election.

links.text: -"David Cameron 'won't serve third term' if re-elected". BBC News. BBC. 23 March 2015. Retrieved 23 March 2015.-

Data.event_text: Janice Atkinson is expelled from UKIP for "bringing the party into disrepute".

links.text: -"UKIP's Janice Atkinson expelled from party". BBC News. BBC. 23 March 2015. Retrieved 23 March 2015.-

Data.event_text: 24 March  UK inflation fell to zero per cent in February, the lowest level since records began, according to official figures.

links.text: -"UK inflation rate falls to zero in February". BBC News. BBC. 24 March 2015. Retrieved 24 March 2015.-

Data.event_text: It is confirmed that three Britons were among those killed when an Airbus A320 crashed into the French Alps the previous day, with no survivors.

links.text: -"Alps air crash killed three Britons, says Hammond". BBC. 25 March 2015. Retrieved 25 March 2015.-

Data.event_text: Following a two-week investigation into a verbal and physical attack on producer Oisin Tymon, the BBC confirms that Top Gear presenter Jeremy Clarkson has been sacked from the programme.

links.text: -"Jeremy Clarkson dropped from Top Gear, BBC confirms". BBC. 25 March 2015. Retrieved 25 March 2015.-

Data.event_text: 26 March  The order of succession to the British throne is changed to absolute primogeniture.
29 March  Police are investigating alleged death threats against BBC Director-General Tony Hall over the decision to sack Jeremy Clarkson from his Top Gear presenting role.

links.text: -Tran, Mark (29 March 2015). "Top Gear fracas: police investigate alleged death threats against BBC boss". The Guardian. Retrieved 29 March 2015.-

Data.event_text: 1 April  English Heritage begins to operate as a charitable trust to manage the nation's portfolio of historic properties, while Historic England is formed to take on its previous functions in statutory planning, advice on and protection of the historic built environment.

2 April  The only televised leaders debate to include Prime Minister David Cameron is aired by ITV. The debate features the leaders of the Conservatives, Labour, the Liberal Democrats, UKIP, the Greens, the Scottish National Party and Plaid Cymru.

links.text: -"Leaders' debate attracts seven million viewers". BBC News. BBC. 3 April 2015. Retrieved 3 April 2015.-

Data.event_text: 27 April  An estimated £200,000,000 worth of jewels are stolen from Hatton Garden Safe Deposit Ltd, Hatton Garden central London, in a meticulously planned heist that takes place over the Easter bank holiday weekend. CCTV footage later emerges, at the website of UK newspaper the Daily Mirror, showing the thieves dressed as building workers and using wheelie bins.
10 April  Police are investigating after it emerged that they received an emergency call from the scene of the Hatton Garden safety deposit raid, but decided not to respond.

links.text: -"Hatton Garden raid: Police failed to respond". BBC News. BBC. 10 April 2015. Retrieved 10 April 2015.-

Data.event_text: Many Clouds, ridden by Leighton Aspell, wins the 2015 Grand National. This is Aspell's second consecutive Grand National win after riding Pineau de Re to victory the previous year.

links.text: -Gheerbrant, James (11 April 2015). "Grand National 2015: Many Clouds wins as McCoy finishes fifth". BBC Sport. BBC. Retrieved 11 April 2015.-

Data.event_text: Oxford beat Cambridge in the first Women's Boat Race to be rowed on the same course on the same day as the men's race (which Oxford also win).

links.text: -Winton, Richard (11 April 2015). "Boat Races 2015: Oxford women and men beat Cambridge". BBC Sport. BBC. Retrieved 11 April 2015.-

Data.event_text: Tennis player Andy Murray marries his fiancée Kim Sears at a ceremony in his home town of Dunblane.

links.text: -"Andy Murray marries girlfriend Kim Sears in Dunblane". BBC News. BBC. 11 April 2015. Retrieved 11 April 2015.-

Data.event_text: 16 April  The Crown Prosecution Service issues a statement indicating that Labour peer Greville Janner will not face prosecution over allegations of child sexual abuse owing to his poor health.

links.text: -"Child abuse case dropped against Labour peer for second time". The Daily Telegraph. 16 April 2015. Retrieved 18 April 2015.-

Data.event_text: 21 April  Following a six-week trial, Justin Robertson is jailed for life with a minimum tariff of thirty-two years for the September 2014 contract killing of Pennie Davis at the behest of her stepson. Benjamin Carr, who paid Robertson £1,500 to carry out the killing, is convicted of conspiracy to murder and will serve at least thirty years.

links.text: -"Life sentence for man guilty of Pennie Davis New Forest murder". BBC News. BBC. 21 April 2015. Retrieved 21 April 2015.-

Data.event_text: 22 April  Supermarket retailer Tesco posts a record £6,400,000,000 annual loss for the year ending in February 2015.Participants in the 2015 London Marathon

Data.event_text: More than 38,000 people take part in this year's London Marathon, making it the biggest in the event's thirty-five-year history.

links.text: -"London Marathon: Thousands take part in biggest race". BBC News. BBC. 26 April 2015. Retrieved 26 April 2015.-

Data.event_text: The government donates £5,000,000 and humanitarian aid to help people affected by the recent earthquake in Nepal, which killed over 6,000 people.

links.text: -"Nepal earthquake: UK government gives £5m". BBC News. BBC. 26 April 2015. Retrieved 26 April 2015.-

Data.event_text: The British Red Cross confirms that there are still dozens of Britons who have still not been traced following the earthquake in Nepal two days earlier.

links.text: -"Nepal earthquake: Dozens of Britons yet to be traced". BBC News. BBC. 27 April 2015. Retrieved 27 April 2015.-

Data.event_text: Former Oxfordshire nurse Andrew Hutchinson is jailed for eighteen years for a rape, sexual assault and voyeurism case involving unconscious women between 2011 and 2013; two of which took place at the John Radcliffe Hospital in Oxford.

links.text: -"Nurse Andrew Hutchinson jailed for attacks on patients". BBC News. BBC. 27 April 2015. Retrieved 27 April 2015.-

Data.event_text: 28 April  Figures show that the rate of economic growth halved to 0.3% in the first quarter, marking the slowest quarterly growth in two years.Clandon Park House catches fire

links.text: -"UK economic growth slows to 0.3%". BBC News. BBC. 28 April 2015. Retrieved 28 April 2015.-

Data.event_text: The UK Supreme Court rules that the government must take immediate action to cut air pollution, following a case brought by lawyers at ClientEarth.

links.text: -"Court orders UK to cut NO2 air pollution". BBC News. BBC. 29 April 2015. Retrieved 29 April 2015.-
-"UK Supreme Court orders Government to take "immediate action" on air pollution". ClientEarth. 29 April 2015. Archived from the original on 5 May 2015. Retrieved 29 April 2015.-
-"UK Supreme Court orders Government to take "immediate action" on air pollution". ClientEarth. 29 April 2015. Archived from the original on 5 May 2015. Retrieved 29 April 2015.-

Data.event_text: 18-year-old Kazi Islam, who was inspired by the murder of Lee Rigby, is convicted by a jury at the Old Bailey of grooming a vulnerable friend to kill two soldiers, and buying ingredients for a pipe bomb.

links.text: -"Teenager Kazi Islam found guilty of terror grooming". BBC News. BBC. 29 April 2015. Retrieved 29 April 2015.-

Data.event_text: The Foreign Office confirms that a Briton living overseas was among the 6,000 victims killed in the Nepal earthquake, and it is feared that another British national has been killed at the Everest Base Camp.

links.text: -"British death in Nepal earthquake confirmed". BBC News. BBC. 29 April 2015. Retrieved 29 April 2015.-

Data.event_text: A blaze causes extensive damage at Clandon Park House, a stately home in Surrey.

links.text: -"Clandon Park House in Surrey hit by major fire". BBC News. BBC. 29 April 2015. Retrieved 30 April 2015.-

Data.event_text: 30 April  The three main political party leaders, David Cameron, Ed Miliband and Nick Clegg, take part in the final televised debate before the general election on a special edition of Question Time.

links.text: -"Leaders grilled by audience in Question Time special". BBC News. BBC. 30 April 2015. Retrieved 30 April 2015.-

Data.event_text: 2 May  The Duchess of Cambridge gives birth to a daughter at St Mary's Hospital in London who becomes fourth in line to the throne and Elizabeth II's fifth great-grandchild. She is subsequently named Charlotte Elizabeth Diana.

links.text: -Davies, Caroline; Ratcliffe, Rebecca (2 May 2015). "Royal baby: Duchess of Cambridge gives birth to baby girl". The Guardian. Retrieved 3 May 2015.-
-"Royal princess named Charlotte Elizabeth Diana". BBC News. BBC. 4 May 2015. Retrieved 20 May 2015.-

Data.event_text: 4 May  The 2015 World Snooker Championship concludes with Stuart Bingham defeating Shaun Murphy 1815 in the final to win his first world title.Election posters in Batley and Spen

links.text: -"Bingham wins World title in thriller". BBC Sport. Retrieved 15 June 2021.-

Data.event_text: 2015 general election The Conservative Party win an outright majority with 331 seats, securing David Cameron a second term in office. Meanwhile, in Scotland, a huge surge to the Scottish National Party sees the party win 56 of the 59 Scottish seats available, an increase of 50 seats compared to their 2010 total. The Labour Party win 232 seats, with modest gains in England more than offset by heavy losses in Scotland, while the Liberal Democrats are almost wiped out with just 8 of their previous 57 seats remaining. UKIP hold one seat and lose one, failing to gain any more despite a huge increase in vote share. The Green Party also hold their sole seat. The Conversatives' majority win is unexpected, as most opinion polls indicated a very tight race, with a high chance of a hung parliament.

links.text: -"UK election results: David Cameron pledges a 'greater Britain'". BBC. 8 May 2015. Retrieved 8 May 2015.-
-"Election 2015: Sturgeon says Scotland 'voted for change'". BBC. 8 May 2015. Retrieved 8 May 2015.-

Data.event_text: 2015 local elections Elections also take place in 279 councils across England, with the Conservatives gaining 25 councils to control 130 overall; the Labour Party lose four seats, leaving them with 67 councils; while the Liberal Democrats lose 4 to control 3 councils.

links.text: -"England council results". BBC. 8 May 2015. Retrieved 8 May 2015.-

Data.event_text: Ed Miliband, Nick Clegg and Nigel Farage, the three respective leaders of the Labour Party, the Liberal Democrats and the UK Independence Party, all announce their resignations in the wake of their electoral defeats.

links.text: -"Labour election results: Ed Miliband resigns as leader". BBC. 8 May 2015. Retrieved 8 May 2015.-
-"Election results: Nick Clegg resigns as Leader of the Liberal Democrats after their worst electoral defeat, seeing them no longer the UK's third party". BBC. 8 May 2015. Retrieved 8 May 2015.-
-"Nigel Farage resigns as UKIP leader". BBC. 8 May 2015. Retrieved 8 May 2015.-

Data.event_text: Commemorations are held to celebrate the seventieth anniversary of VE Day, the end of World War II on the continent.

links.text: -"VE Day 70th anniversary marked with events across Europe". BBC. 8 May 2015. Retrieved 8 May 2015.-

Data.event_text: Nigel Farage announces he will stay on as UKIP leader, reversing his previous decision to resign, after the party rejects his resignation, saying there is "overwhelming evidence" that members disagree with his decision to quit.

links.text: -"Farage stays as UKIP leader after resignation rejected". BBC. 11 May 2015. Retrieved 13 May 2015.-

Data.event_text: Figures show that unemployment fell to 1,830,000 in the first quarter, a 35,000 decrease from the last quarter, and the lowest figure in seven years.

links.text: -"UK unemployment falls to seven-year low". BBC. 13 May 2015. Retrieved 13 May 2015.-

Data.event_text: 15 May  The Rail, Maritime and Transport workers union (RMT) announce that Network Rail workers will stage a 24-hour strike from 5.00pm on 25 May over pay and conditions, the first national rail strike in the UK for two decades. The strike is called off on 21 May after a pay deal is reached with Network Rail management.

links.text: -"Rail workers to strike on bank holiday Monday". BBC News. BBC. 15 May 2015. Retrieved 20 May 2015.-
-"Rail unions call off national bank holiday strike". BBC News. BBC. 21 May 2015. Retrieved 21 May 2015.-

Data.event_text: 16 May  The Church of Scotland votes to allow the ordination of gay ministers in civil partnerships.

links.text: -"Church of Scotland votes to allow gay ministers in civil partnerships". BBC. 16 May 2015. Retrieved 16 May 2015.-

Data.event_text: Prince Charles begins his official four-day tour of the Republic of Ireland having a controversial meeting with Sinn Féin leader Gerry Adams.

links.text: -"Prince Charles meets Sinn Féin leader Gerry Adams". BBC. 19 May 2015. Retrieved 19 May 2015.-

Data.event_text: Figures show that the main measure of inflation turned negative in April for the first time on record, falling to −0.1%.

links.text: -"UK inflation rate turns negative". BBC. 19 May 2015. Retrieved 19 May 2015.-

Data.event_text: Nine men are arrested, and eight charged the following day, in connection with the Hatton Garden safe deposit raid in early April.

links.text: -"Hatton Garden raid: Nine men arrested". BBC. 19 May 2015. Retrieved 21 May 2015.-
-"Hatton Garden raid: Eight men charged over burglary heist". BBC. 20 May 2015. Retrieved 21 May 2015.-

Data.event_text: 21 May  Cashless payments now exceed the use of notes and coins, with cash volumes expected to fall by 30% over the next ten years, according to the Payments Council.

links.text: -"Cashless payments overtake the use of notes and coins". BBC. 21 May 2015. Retrieved 21 May 2015.-

Data.event_text: 22 May  An earthquake of magnitude 4.2 is felt across East Kent.

links.text: -"Kent earthquake causes homes to shake". BBC. 22 May 2015. Retrieved 23 May 2015.-

Data.event_text: 28 May  The RMT calls two national strikes for June after failing to reach a deal with Network Rail management. A 24-hour strike will begin at 5.00pm on 4 June, and a 48-hour strike will take place from 5.00pm on 9 June. The strikes are suspended on 1 June, after a 2% salary increase offer from Network Rail.

links.text: -"Network Rail workers to go on strike in June". BBC News. BBC. 28 May 2015. Retrieved 28 May 2015.-
-"UK rail strikes suspended after 2% pay rise offer". BBC News. BBC. 1 June 2015. Retrieved 2 June 2015.-

Data.event_text: 30 May  In football, Arsenal win the 2015 FA Cup Final defeating Aston Villa 40 at Wembley.
National rail strikes planned for 4 and 9 June are called off after a pay deal is reached.

links.text: -"ACAS – Network rail strikes called off". ITV News. 1 June 2015. Retrieved 2 June 2015.-

Data.event_text: Charles Kennedy, former leader of the Liberal Democrats, dies aged 55 in Fort William, Scotland, of haemorrhage linked to alcoholism.

links.text: -"Tributes paid to Charles Kennedy". BBC News. BBC. 2 June 2015.-

Data.event_text: 2 June  A serious collision on The Smiler ride at Alton Towers causes four people to be airlifted to hospital due to their injuries. The incident is one of the biggest accidents ever to occur at Alton Towers, and the park is closed for several days pending investigations.

links.text: -"Alton Towers Smiler crash: Four seriously hurt". BBC News. 2 June 2015. Retrieved 5 June 2015.-

Data.event_text: 3 June  Jo Cox gives her maiden speech in Parliament.

links.text: -Keogh, Frank. "Frankie Dettori wins Epsom Derby on favourite Golden Horn". BBC Sport. Retrieved 9 June 2015.-

Data.event_text: 9 June  HSBC, the world's largest banking retailer, announce plans to cut 25,000 jobs worldwide, including 8,000 in the UK. It also plans to close some of its UK branches, and rename the HSBC brand in the UK.

links.text: -"HSBC plans to cut 8,000 jobs in the UK in savings drive". BBC News. 9 June 2015. Retrieved 9 June 2015.-

Data.event_text: Chancellor George Osborne announces government plans to sell off its stake in the Royal Bank of Scotland.

links.text: -"RBS government stake to be sold, chancellor announces". BBC News. 11 June 2015. Retrieved 11 June 2015.-

Data.event_text: A nationwide poll to find a national bird for the UK chooses the robin as the public's favourite candidate.

-Hardy, Jack (10 June 2015). "Robin crowned as Britain's national bird after 200,000-strong ballot". The Independent. Independent Print Limited. Archived from the original on 1 May 2022. Retrieved 10 June 2015.-

Data.event_text: 11 June  A youth is detained by police after a teacher is stabbed in front of students at a school in Bradford.

links.text: -"Boy arrested after Bradford teacher stabbing". BBC News. 11 June 2015. Retrieved 12 June 2015.-

Data.event_text: 13 June  Trooping the Colour takes place in London marking the Queen's official birthday. It is the Duchess of Cambridge's first appearance since the birth of Princess Charlotte. Prince George also makes his first appearance on the balcony of Buckingham Palace.
14 June  A statue of Queen Elizabeth II is unveiled by Speaker John Bercow at Runnymede in Surrey ahead of the celebrations of Magna Carta.

links.text: -"Statue of the Queen unveiled to mark Magna Carta milestone". ITV News. ITV. 14 June 2015. Retrieved 15 June 2015.-

-"Queen attends 800th anniversary ceremony". BBC News. 15 June 2015. Retrieved 15 June 2015.-

Data.event_text: 18 June  A government report reveals that the Palace of Westminster is in need of repair, and recommends that MPs leave the building for two years in order for the repairs to be carried out.

links.text: -"MPs face House of Commons move while palace is repaired". Financial Times. 19 June 2015. Retrieved 24 June 2015.-

Data.event_text: 20 June  Some 250,000 people take to the streets in cities such as London, Bristol and Manchester in a demonstration backed by the People's Assembly Against Austerity to protest against the UK Government's austerity programme.

links.text: -"Queen could move out of Buckingham Palace". BBC News. 24 June 2015. Retrieved 24 June 2015.-

Data.event_text: 25 June  The UK population has grown by almost 500,000 to reach 64,596,800 in 2014  an above average increase compared with increases over the last decade – according to the Office for National Statistics (ONS). The percentage of older people continues to increase, and the median age is now forty years, the highest ever recorded.

links.text: -"UK population increases by 500,000, official figures show". BBC News. 25 June 2015. Retrieved 25 June 2015.-

-"British Tunisia death toll rises to 15". BBC News. 27 June 2015. Retrieved 27 June 2015.-
-"Memorial On Beach After 30 Britons Killed". Sky News. British Sky Broadcasting. 30 June 2015. Retrieved 5 July 2015.-

Data.event_text: The 14th Dalai Lama makes an appearance at the 2015 Glastonbury Festival, praising the event as "a festival of people, not governments or politicians".

-"Hatfield Colliery closure speeds up UK exit from deep coal mining". London: Reuters. 30 June 2015. Archived from the original on 23 July 2015. Retrieved 19 July 2015.-

Data.event_text: 30 June  Police officers, intelligence officials, soldiers and emergency services take part in a counter-terrorism exercise, codenamed Strong Tower, in London. The terror attack simulation has been six months in the planning and is the country's largest such exercise to date.

Data.event_text: 1 July  A level three "heatwave action" heat-health alert is declared by the Met Office, as a temperature of 36.7 °C is recorded at Heathrow in London; the hottest UK temperature in twelve years, and the hottest July day on record.

links.text: -"Hottest July day ever recorded in England". BBC News. BBC . 1 July 2015. Retrieved 1 July 2015.-

Data.event_text: Across the UK, a one-minute silence is held at midday to remember the 38 victims  including 30 British people  who died in the Tunisia beach attack a week earlier.

Data.event_text: 4 July  England finish third in the 2015 Women's World Cup after defeating Germany 10 in the third place play-off.

links.text: -Magowan, Alistair (4 July 2015). "Women's World Cup: Germany Women 0–1 England Women". BBC Sport. BBC. Retrieved 5 July 2015.-

links.text: -"7 July London bombings: Ceremonies in memory of victims". BBC News. 7 July 2015. Retrieved 7 July 2015.-

Data.event_text: 8 July  As part of his first Conservative Budget, the Chancellor George Osborne unveils billions in welfare cuts, but also announces a National Living Wage of £9 an hour by 2020.

links.text: -"Budget 2015: Osborne unveils National Living Wage". BBC News. 8 July 2015. Retrieved 8 July 2015.-

Data.event_text: Production ceases at the last deep coal mine in Nottinghamshire, Thoresby Colliery.

Data.event_text: Thousands of British holidaymakers begin to return home from Tunisia after a warning from the Foreign Office that another terror attack is "highly likely".

Data.event_text: 13 July  Hundreds of flights are disrupted at Heathrow Airport in London after members of the climate change protest group Plane Stupid break through the metal fence, get onto the northern runway, and chain themselves together in protest.Tim Farron, newly elected leader of the Liberal Democrats

links.text: -"Heathrow Airport climate change protest delays flights". BBC News. 13 July 2015. Retrieved 13 July 2015.-

Data.event_text: 16 July  Tim Farron is elected as the new leader of the Liberal Democrats.

links.text: -"Tim Farron elected as Leader of the Liberal Democrats". Liberal Democrats. 16 July 2015. Retrieved 23 September 2015.-

Data.event_text: The first female genital mutilation protection order in the UK is obtained by Bedfordshire Police, preventing two young girls thought to be at risk from travelling to Africa.

links.text: -"UK's first FGM protection order secured by Beds police". BBC News. 17 July 2015. Retrieved 17 July 2015.-

Data.event_text: Four people are thought to be trapped and four others are taken to hospital, after three explosions at a wood treatment works in Bosley near Macclesfield in Cheshire.

links.text: -"Bosley explosion: 'Four missing' in Wood Flour Mills blast". BBC News. 17 July 2015. Retrieved 17 July 2015.-

Data.event_text: 20 July  In golf, Zach Johnson of the USA wins the 2015 Open Championship, the 144th edition of the tournament, at St Andrews, Fife, defeating South Africa's Louis Oosthuizen and Marc Leishman of Australia in a playoff.

21 July  Chancellor George Osborne launches a spending review that calls for £20 billion of cuts to Whitehall budgets. Each unprotected department is asked to create savings plans of between 25% and 40% of their budget.

links.text: -"Draw up 40% cuts plans, George Osborne tells Whitehall departments". BBC News. 21 July 2015. Retrieved 21 July 2015.-

Data.event_text: 22 July  The University of Birmingham finds in its archives the oldest known surviving fragments of the Koran, and plans to put them on public display.

links.text: -"'Oldest' Koran fragments found in Birmingham University". BBC News. 22 July 2015. Retrieved 22 July 2015.-

Data.event_text: 26 July  Great Britain's Chris Froome wins the 2015 Tour de France. This is Froome's second victory in the event, having also won the race in 2013, and marks the third time in four years that the event has been won by a British rider.

links.text: -"Tour de France: Chris Froome seals historic second win". BBC News. 27 July 2015. Retrieved 27 July 2015.-

Data.event_text: Members of the Norwich sexual abuse ring are found guilty of the sexual abuse of children, with the crimes spanning a decade. Ringleader Marie Black is convicted of 23 counts of sex abuse, including rape.

links.text: -"Norfolk child sex abuse case: Marie Black guilty". BBC News. 27 July 2015.-

Data.event_text: A train is derailed at Chilham in Kent after hitting cows on the line, but the passengers manage to escape unharmed.

links.text: -"Train derailed after hitting cows on line in Kent". BBC News. 27 July 2015. Retrieved 27 July 2015.-

Data.event_text: The Metropolitan Police launch a criminal investigation after Lord Sewel, the former Deputy Lords Speaker, is filmed allegedly taking cocaine with prostitutes.

links.text: -"Police investigating drug claim peer". BBC News. 27 July 2015. Retrieved 27 July 2015.-

Data.event_text: 28 July  The Eurotunnel migrant crisis worsens as its reported that 2,000 migrants tried to enter the Channel Tunnel terminal in Calais in an attempt to reach the UK the previous night.

links.text: -"Channel Tunnel: '2,000 migrants' tried to enter". BBC News. 28 July 2015. Retrieved 28 July 2015.-

Data.event_text: 31 July  A private jet crashes at a car auction site near Blackbushe Airport in Hampshire, killing its pilot and three passengers.

links.text: -"Blackbushe Airport: Four dead in car auction site plane crash". BBC News. 31 July 2015. Retrieved 31 July 2015.-

Data.event_text: 1 August  Singer and television star Cilla Black, whose showbiz career spanned over fifty years, dies at her villa in Spain, aged 72.

links.text: -"Cilla Black, singer and TV star, dies in Spain aged 72". BBC. 2 August 2015. Retrieved 2 August 2015.-

Data.event_text: 4 August  Former prime minister Sir Edward Heath, who died in 2005, is investigated by police forces as part of their inquiries into allegations of historical child abuse.

links.text: -"Edward Heath abuse claims: Four forces investigating ex-PM". BBC. 4 August 2015. Retrieved 4 August 2015.-

Data.event_text: 6 August  A second transport worker's strike causes chaos in London, with the entire London Underground network shut down.

links.text: -"Tube strike – London commuters deal with queues and delays". BBC. 6 August 2015. Retrieved 7 August 2015.-

Data.event_text: 10 August  The youth who stabbed teacher Vincent Uzomah at a Bradford school on 11 June is sentenced to eleven years' detention.

Data.event_text: 8 September - England Footballer Wayne Rooney becomes the England national football team all-time leading goalscorer with 50 goals in a 20 win vs Switzerland national football team, surpassing the previous record of 49 goals held by Sir Bobby Charlton since 1968. Data.event_text: 22 September  Chancellor George Osborne says during a visit to China that the country "must be the United Kingdom's number two export market".

Data.event_text: 26 September  A fire damages the United Kingdom's largest mosque, the Baitul Futuh Mosque in Morden, London.

links.text: -"Morden mosque fire: 70 firefighters tackle blaze". BBC. 26 September 2015. Retrieved 26 September 2015.-

Data.event_text: Members of a Norwich sexual abuse ring are jailed for "utterly depraved" sex abuse of children over a period of ten years. Ringleader Marie Black received the longest sentence of life imprisonment, with a minimum term of 24 years.

links.text: -"Marie Black gets life term for child abuse". BBC News. 28 September 2015.-

Data.event_text: Steelmaker SSI, owner of the Teesside Steelworks at Redcar in North Yorkshire, announces that it is to close, with the loss of 1,700 jobs.

links.text: -"SSI Redcar steel plant mothballed, with the loss of 1,700 jobs". BBC. 28 September 2015. Retrieved 29 September 2015.-

Data.event_text: Volkswagen announces that 1,200,000 of its vehicles sold in the UK are affected by the software behind the emissions scandal, including cars with the VW brand, Audi, Seat, Skodă and VW vans.

links.text: -"VW scandal: 1.2m UK vehicles affected". BBC. 30 September 2015. Retrieved 30 September 2015.-

Data.event_text: David Cameron faces demands from campaigners to apologise and pay financial reparations for the United Kingdom's role in the historic slave trade in the Caribbean, during a state visit to Jamaica. Government loans taken out to compensate slaveowners under the Slavery Abolition Act 1833 are finally repaid this year.

links.text: -"David Cameron faces demands for slavery reparation on Jamaica visit". BBC. 30 September 2015. Retrieved 30 September 2015.-
-Manjapra, Kris (29 March 2018). "When will Britain face up to its crimes against humanity?". The Guardian. Retrieved 30 March 2018.-

Data.event_text: Doctors are granted approval by the Health Research Authority to carry out the first ten womb transplants in the UK, following the success of the procedure in Sweden.

links.text: -"Womb transplants given UK go-ahead". BBC. 30 September 2015. Retrieved 30 September 2015.-

Data.event_text: A new law banning smoking in vehicles carrying children comes into force in England and Wales.

links.text: -"Car smoking ban comes into force". BBC. 1 October 2015. Retrieved 2 October 2015.-

Data.event_text: New consumer protections come into force under the Consumer Rights Act, guaranteeing a full refund for faulty goods up to thirty days after purchase.

links.text: -"Right to 30-day refund becomes law". BBC. 1 October 2015. Retrieved 1 October 2015.-

Data.event_text: 2 October  A 15-year old British boy from Blackburn, who plotted to behead police officers at an Anzac Day parade in Australia, is sentenced to life in prison.

links.text: -"Anzac Day terror plot: Blackburn boy sentenced to life". BBC. 2 October 2015. Retrieved 2 October 2015.-

Data.event_text: A woman and an eight-year-old boy are killed and several others are seriously injured, after a double-decker bus crashes into a supermarket in Coventry.

links.text: -Howell, Dominic (3 October 2015). "Coventry bus crash: Two dead after double-decker hits supermarket". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 4 October 2015.-

Data.event_text: Two people are killed after their light aircraft crashes into a field near Chigwell in Essex.

links.text: -"Chigwell air crash: two dead after aircraft bursts into flames". BBC. 3 October 2015. Retrieved 3 October 2015.-

Data.event_text: Denis Healey, former Chancellor of the Exchequer and Deputy Leader of the Labour Party, dies, aged 98.

links.text: -"'Labour giant' Denis Healey dies at 98". BBC News. 3 October 2015.-

Data.event_text: England becomes the last country in the UK to introduce a mandatory 5p charge for plastic carrier bags at supermarkets.

links.text: -Howell, Dominic (2 October 2015). "The 5p plastic bag charge: All you need to know". BBC News. BBC. Retrieved 3 October 2015.-

Data.event_text: Archaeologists start digging up the remains of a Spitfire that crashed in the Cambridgeshire fens in 1940.

links.text: -"World War 2 Spitfire to be unearthed from Cambridgeshire fen". BBC. 5 October 2015. Retrieved 5 October 2015.-

Data.event_text: 6 October  Merseyside Police begin a major search after one of their officers, David Phillips, dies the previous night after being hit by a stolen pick-up truck he was trying to stop.

links.text: -"PC David Phillips murder: Police hunt driver of stolen truck". BBC. 6 October 2015. Retrieved 6 October 2015.-

Data.event_text: 12 October  University College Chichester, in West Sussex, is recognised as a full university, the University of Chichester.

13 October  Home Office figures show that hate crimes in England and Wales have risen by 18% from the last year; with 80% classed as race hate crimes, and others involving religion, disability, sexuality and transgender victims.

links.text: -"Hate crimes increase by 18% in England and Wales". BBC. 13 October 2015. Retrieved 13 October 2015.-

Data.event_text: 15 October  The Stirling Prize, the United Kingdom's top architectural award, is given to Burntwood School in Wandsworth, London.

links.text: -"Riba Stirling Prize: Burntwood School wins award". BBC. 15 October 2015. Retrieved 15 October 2015.-

Data.event_text: 16 October  Scottish National Party leader Nicola Sturgeon announces at the annual SNP conference, that party membership now stands at 114,221 members.

links.text: -"SNP Conference 2015: Who are the party's new members?". BBC. 16 October 2015. Retrieved 23 October 2015.-

Data.event_text: 19 October  Chinese President Xi Jinping arrives at Heathrow Airport for his first state visit to the UK.

links.text: -"Chinese President Xi Jinping arrives in UK". BBC News. BBC. 19 October 2015.-

Data.event_text: 21 October  Michael Meacher, the Labour MP for Oldham West and Royton, dies in office.

links.text: -"Labour MP Michael Meacher dies". BBC. 21 October 2015. Retrieved 21 October 2015.-

Data.event_text: 22 October  The voting rights of MPs representing constituencies in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland are to be restricted, after the Conservative Government wins a vote on its controversial 'English votes for English laws’ (EVEL) plans.

links.text: -"Voting rights of Scottish MPs to be restricted after Government wins Evel vote". The Herald. 22 October 2015. Retrieved 23 October 2015.-

Data.event_text: 23 October  A "significant and sustained" cyberattack is made on the website of telecoms firm TalkTalk, with personal and banking details of up to 4,000,000 customers being accessed and the firm's CEO receiving a ransom email purported to be from the hackers.

links.text: -"TalkTalk cyber-attack: Boss 'receives ransom email'". BBC. 23 October 2015. Retrieved 23 October 2015.-

Data.event_text: The Royal Mint releases a special £5 coin to commemorate the 600th anniversary of the Battle of Agincourt.

links.text: -"Royal Mint releases coin to mark Battle of Agincourt anniversary". BBC. 25 October 2015. Retrieved 26 October 2015.-

Data.event_text: Five people, all confirmed to be Britons, are drowned after the whale-watching boat Leviathan II sinks off Tofino in British Columbia, Canada.

links.text: -"Whale-watching boat tragedy kills five Britons". Sky News. 26 October 2015. Retrieved 27 October 2015.-

Data.event_text: Rachel Treweek, Bishop of Gloucester, becomes the first woman to take her seat as a bishop in the House of Lords.

links.text: -"Gloucester bishop Rachel Treweek to take seat in Lords". BBC News. BBC. 26 October 2015. Retrieved 26 October 2015.-

Data.event_text: The government suffers a major defeat in the House of Lords, after its plans to cut tax credits are rejected by peers, who vote to delay the measures and compensate those affected in full.

links.text: -"Tax credits: Lords vote to delay controversial cuts". BBC. 26 October 2015. Retrieved 29 October 2015.-

Data.event_text: A 16-year-old youth is detained by police, after a fellow pupil is stabbed to death at Cults Academy school in Aberdeen.

links.text: -"Pupil dies after school stabbing at Cults Academy near Aberdeen". BBC News. BBC. 29 October 2015. Retrieved 29 October 2015.-

Data.event_text: It is projected that the UK population will increase beyond 70,000,000 by 2027, mainly due to an ageing population and net migration.

links.text: -"UK population 'to top 70 million in 12 years'". BBC News. BBC. 29 October 2015. Retrieved 30 October 2015.-

Data.event_text: 30 October  Shaker Aamer, the last British resident to be held in Guantanamo Bay, lands in the UK, having been detained for thirteen years.

links.text: -"Shaker Aamer: Last UK Guantanamo Bay detainee arrives in UK". BBC News. BBC. 30 October 2015. Retrieved 30 October 2015.-

Data.event_text: 31 October  A motorist dies and ten people are taken to hospital with injuries, after a car collides with a bus near West Kilbride in Ayrshire, Scotland.

links.text: -"Driver dies and two seriously injured in crash between car and bus". BBC. 31 October 2015. Retrieved 31 October 2015.-

Data.event_text: 1 November  A temperature of 22.4 °C is recorded in Trawsgoed, Ceredigion in Wales, making it the warmest November day on record in the UK, breaking the previous record set nearly seventy years ago.

links.text: -"Hottest UK November day recorded in mid Wales". BBC. 1 November 2015. Retrieved 1 November 2015.-

Data.event_text: Archaeologists accidentally discover a well-preserved family burial vault in Gloucester Cathedral.

links.text: -"Burial vault discovered 'accidentally' at Gloucester Cathedral". BBC. 2 November 2015. Retrieved 2 November 2015.-

Data.event_text: Hundreds of police officers from all over the UK turn out to pay their respects at the funeral of Merseyside Police officer David Phillips at Liverpool Cathedral.

links.text: -"PC David Phillips funeral: Hundreds of police officers attend". BBC. 2 November 2015. Retrieved 2 November 2015.-

Data.event_text: 4 November  A suspension of flights between the UK and the Egyptian holiday resort of Sharm el-Sheikh leaves many British holidaymakers stranded, following rumours that the Metrojet Flight 9268 on 31 October, in which many Russian tourists died, was caused by a terrorist bomb.

links.text: -"Anger in Russian media at Britain stopping Sharm el-Sheikh flights". The Guardian. 5 November 2015. Retrieved 6 November 2015.-

Data.event_text: 5 November  A protest march by masked anti-capitalists in central London on Bonfire Night leads to three Metropolitan Police officers being taken to hospital with injuries. Six police horses are also hurt.

links.text: -"Million Mask March: Three police officers hospitalised". BBC. 6 November 2015. Retrieved 6 November 2015.-

Data.event_text: 6 November  Flights between the UK and Sharm el-Sheikh resume, bringing the stranded British tourists home.

links.text: -"Russian plane crash: First flights return to UK after Sharm alert". BBC. 6 November 2015. Retrieved 6 November 2015.-

Data.event_text: 10 November  Storm Abigail is the first storm to be officially named by the Met Office. It leaves many travel services disrupted, schools closed, and 20,000 homes without power.

links.text: -"Met Office officially names Abigail as first storm". Met Office. Retrieved 10 November 2015.-
-"Storm Abigail sweeps through Scotland cutting power". BBC. 14 November 2015. Retrieved 14 November 2015.-

Data.event_text: 11 November  The stepbrother of murdered teenager Becky Watts, Nathan Matthews is found guilty of her murder and his girlfriend, Sauna Hoare, found guilty of Becky Watts' manslaughter.

links.text: -"Pair guilty of Becky Watts killing". BBC News.-

Data.event_text: One Briton is confirmed to be among the 129 people killed in a series of coordinated terrorist attacks in Paris the previous day, with fears of a "handful" more to be confirmed.

links.text: -"Paris attacks: Briton confirmed among dead". BBC. 14 November 2015. Retrieved 15 November 2015.-

Data.event_text: Gatwick's North Terminal is evacuated as a precautionary measure, in light of the terrorist attacks in Paris, after a man is arrested when a suspicious item is found at the airport.

links.text: -"French man held as suspected firearm found at Gatwick Airport". BBC. 14 November 2015. Retrieved 14 November 2015.-

Data.event_text: The Department for Transport announces that all speed cameras in England currently painted grey will be repainted yellow by the end of October 2016.

links.text: -"Grey speed cameras to be turned yellow under new rules". BBC. 14 November 2015. Retrieved 14 November 2015.-

Data.event_text: A family of four are killed after their six-seater light aircraft crashes near Churchinford in Somerset.

links.text: -"Four people dead as plane crashes in Somerset". BBC. 14 November 2015. Retrieved 14 November 2015.-
-"Somerset plane crash dead 'from the same family'". BBC. 15 November 2015. Retrieved 15 November 2015.-

Data.event_text: 16 November  The UK joins the rest of Europe in a minutes silence in remembrance of the 129 lives lost, including one Briton, in the Paris terrorist attacks on 13 November.

links.text: -"UK falls silent for the victims of the Paris attacks". BBC. 16 November 2015. Retrieved 16 November 2015.-

Data.event_text: 17 November  Prime Minister David Cameron promises the House of Commons a "comprehensive strategy" to win MPs' backing for bombing Islamic State militants in Syria as well as Iraq.

links.text: -"PM: I will make case for strikes against IS in Syria". BBC. 17 November 2015. Retrieved 17 November 2015.-

Data.event_text: Thousands of homes are left without power as Storm Barney rips through parts of the United Kingdom.

links.text: -"Thousands left without power as Storm Barney batters UK". The Telegraph. 18 November 2015. Retrieved 18 November 2015.-

Data.event_text: Energy Secretary Amber Rudd proposes that the UK's coal plants should be phased out by 2025.

links.text: -"UK's coal plants to be phased out within 10 years". BBC. 18 November 2015. Retrieved 18 November 2015.-

Data.event_text: 21 November  Four Britons are believed to be among the seven people killed in a helicopter crash on the Fox Glacier in South Island, New Zealand.

links.text: -"'Four Britons and two Australians' among NZ crash dead". BBC. 21 November 2015. Retrieved 21 November 2015.-

Data.event_text: 23 November  David Cameron holds talks with French President François Hollande about co-operation in the fight against Islamic State.

links.text: -"David Cameron: World uniting to fight 'evil threat' of IS". BBC. 23 November 2015. Retrieved 23 November 2015.-

Data.event_text: A Scottish National Party motion opposing Trident's renewal is defeated by 330 votes to 64, with most Labour MPs abstaining.

links.text: -MPs reject SNP calls for Trident to be scrapped bbc.co.uk, accessed 26 December 2015-

Data.event_text: Alton Towers confirms that The Smiler rollercoaster crash, that seriously injured five people in June, was caused by human error.

links.text: -"Alton Towers Smiler ride crash due to 'human error'". BBC. 24 November 2015. Retrieved 24 November 2015.-

Data.event_text: British Airways and EasyJet cancel all flights between Sharm el-Sheikh and the UK until January, following the suspected bombing of Metrojet Flight 9268.

links.text: -"Egypt plane crash: Airlines cancel more Sharm el-Sheikh flights". BBC. 24 November 2015. Retrieved 24 November 2015.-

Data.event_text: 25 November  Chancellor George Osborne outlines his joint annual Autumn Statement and Spending Review for the financial year ahead, in which he surprisingly announces he is to scrap planned cuts to tax credits and vows to protect police budgets in response to the UK's heightened terror threat.

links.text: -"Spending Review: George Osborne U-turn over tax credits". BBC. 25 November 2015. Retrieved 25 November 2015.-
-"Spending Review: George Osborne protects police funding". BBC. 25 November 2015. Retrieved 25 November 2015.-

Data.event_text: 28 November  Grant Shapps quits as Minister of State at the Department for International Development amid claims he failed to act on allegations of bullying following the apparent suicide of a youth activist in September.

links.text: -"Grant Shapps quits amid Tory bullying claims". BBC. 28 November 2015. Retrieved 28 November 2015.-

Data.event_text: 29 November  In tennis, Great Britain win the Davis Cup for the first time since 1936 after Andy Murray beats Belgium's David Goffin at the final in Ghent, Belgium.

links.text: -"Andy Murray wins the Davis Cup for Great Britain". BBC. 29 November 2015. Retrieved 29 November 2015.-

Data.event_text: November  Last sighting in England of a golden eagle (in the Lake District).

links.text: -Aldred, Jessica (14 April 2016). "England's last golden eagle feared dead". The Guardian. London. Retrieved 12 March 2023.-

Data.event_text: 1 December  A fire damages a bar in Newcastle city centre, and one person, later confirmed as the owner, Brian Sandals, is found burnt to death.Protest against air strikes in Syria

links.text: -"Newcastle Kard Bar fire: Body believed to be Brian Sandals". BBC. 2 December 2015. Retrieved 3 December 2015.-

Data.event_text: 2 December  MPs vote 397223 to authorise UK air strikes against Islamic State in Syria.

links.text: -"Syria air strikes: MPs authorise UK action against Islamic State". BBC. 2 December 2015. Retrieved 2 December 2015.-

Data.event_text: The UK launches its first air strikes over Syria with RAF tornado jets carrying out bombings against Islamic State-controlled oil fields.

links.text: -"UK launches first Syria air strikes". BBC. 3 December 2015. Retrieved 3 December 2015.-

Data.event_text: 2015 Oldham West and Royton by-election Jim McMahon retains the seat for Labour with an increased majority of 7.3%. The by-election was caused by long-serving MP Michael Meacher's death in October.
The Rail Delivery Group announces that rail fares will rise by 1.1% in the new year, in line with current inflation rates.

links.text: -"Rail fares to rise by average of 1.1% from 2 January". BBC. 4 December 2015. Retrieved 5 December 2015.-

Data.event_text: The Forth Road Bridge in Scotland is closed due to structural defects, and the Scottish Transport Minister, Derek Mackay, announces that it will not be reopened until .

links.text: -"Forth Road Bridge to be closed until new year". BBC. 4 December 2015. Retrieved 5 December 2015.-

Data.event_text: A stabbing at Leytonstone tube station in East London, which leaves a man with serious knife injuries, is being treated as a "terrorist incident" according to the Metropolitan Police.

links.text: -"Leytonstone Tube stabbing 'terrorist incident'". BBC. 5 December 2015. Retrieved 5 December 2015.-

Data.event_text: Storm Desmond batters the UK with high-speed winds and heavy rain, causing severe disruption. People are evacuated from their homes as flash flooding sweeps through parts of Cumbria, with police declaring a "major incident".

links.text: -"Storm Desmond brings flooding and disruption to parts of UK". BBC. 5 December 2015. Retrieved 5 December 2015.-

Data.event_text: Plastic bag use in Tesco stores in England has declined by 80% since a new 5p charge was introduced, data suggests.

links.text: -"Tesco plastic bag use 'down 80%' since 5p charge". BBC. 5 December 2015. Retrieved 5 December 2015.-

Data.event_text: The Election Court decide that although Liberal Democrat Alistair Carmichael has told a "blatant lie" in a TV interview, it has not been proven beyond reasonable doubt that he had committed an "illegal practice" that would invalidate his election.

links.text: -"Alistair Carmichael case: Legal bid to oust Lib Dem MP fails". BBC News. 9 December 2015. Retrieved 9 December 2015.-

Data.event_text: MPs debate whether Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump should be banned from entering the UK after an online petition receives an excess of 100,000 signatures. This follows Trump making a statement about banning all Muslims from entering the United States, and claims he made that parts of London are "so radicalised the police are afraid for their lives".

links.text: -"Trump UK ban petition passes 250,000 signatures". BBC. 9 December 2015. Retrieved 9 December 2015.-
-"Trump claim wrong that police 'afraid' in London – PM says". BBC. 9 December 2015. Retrieved 9 December 2015.-

Data.event_text: Chancellor George Osborne announces a £50,000,000 fund for families and businesses hit by floods in Cumbria and Lancashire in the wake of Storm Desmond.

links.text: -"Storm Desmond: £50m flood fund pledged for victims". BBC. 9 December 2015. Retrieved 9 December 2015.-

Data.event_text: 10 December  The government announces that any decisions on whether to allow a new runway at Heathrow or Gatwick will not be announced until summer 2016.

links.text: -"Heathrow Airport runway decision delayed until summer". BBC. 10 December 2015. Retrieved 11 December 2015.-

Data.event_text: 14 December  A "huge rise" is reported in the number of newborn babies in England who are subject to care proceedings, with 2,018 in 2013 compared to 802 in 2008.Tim Peake conducting repairs on the international space station a few weeks after his arrival

links.text: -"'Huge rise' in newborn babies subject to care proceedings". BBC. 14 December 2015. Retrieved 30 December 2015.-

Data.event_text: 15 December  British astronaut Tim Peake becomes the first Briton under the banner of the European Space Agency to set foot on the International Space Station.

links.text: -"Tim Peake begins stay on international space station". BBC. 15 December 2015. Retrieved 12 January 2016.-

Data.event_text: The United Kingdom's last deep coal mine, Kellingley Colliery at Beal, North Yorkshire, closes; marking the end of the era of deep-pit coal mining in the UK.

links.text: -"Sadness tinged with relief for miners as Kellingley Colliery closure date set". Yorkshire Evening Post. 11 December 2015. Archived from the original on 22 December 2015. Retrieved 18 December 2015.-

-"Sadness tinged with relief for miners as Kellingley Colliery closure date set". Yorkshire Evening Post. 11 December 2015. Archived from the original on 22 December 2015. Retrieved 18 December 2015.-

Data.event_text: Energy firm npower is fined £26,000,000 over billing and complaint failures after it sent out incorrect bills and failed to deal with complaints, according to Ofgem.

links.text: -"Npower to pay £26m over billing and complaint failures". BBC. 18 December 2015. Retrieved 30 December 2015.-

Data.event_text: 25 December  Storm Eva causes more intensive flooding in northern England, with homes evacuated in Lancashire and Yorkshire, and rivers overflowing in Manchester and Leeds.

links.text: -"UK floods: Homes evacuated amid heavy rain". BBC. 27 December 2015. Retrieved 30 December 2015.-

Data.event_text: 29 December  An 81-year-old woman is shot dead by a fellow octogenarian resident at the De La Mer House care home in Essex.

links.text: -"De La Mer House care home shooting: Woman killed". BBC. 29 December 2015. Retrieved 30 December 2015.-

Data.event_text: A husband and wife who plotted terror attacks in the Underground and Westfield shopping centre, nicknamed the "silent bomber" couple, are jailed for a minimum of 27 and 25 years.

links.text: -"'Silent bomber' couple jailed for London terror plot". BBC. 30 December 2015. Retrieved 30 December 2015.-

Data.event_text: Hundreds of homes are evacuated and thousands are left without power in Scotland and Northern Ireland as Storm Frank brings torrential rain and gales. More than a hundred flood warnings are issued across England, Wales and Scotland.

links.text: -"UK floods: Homes evacuated amid heavy rain". BBC. 30 December 2015. Retrieved 30 December 2015.-

Data.event_text: The New Year honours list is announced, with new knights, dames, MBEs and OBEs awarded for notable contributions to society.

links.text: -"New Year honours 2016: the full list". The Guardian. 30 December 2015.-

Data.event_text: More than 1,700 same-sex couples have married in the first year after Scotland became the seventeenth country in the world to legalise same-sex marriage.

links.text: -"More that 1,700 same-sex couples married in first year of law". BBC News. 31 December 2015. Retrieved 1 February 2023.-
